comments:
This course examines the history, doctrines, and practices of Zen Buddhism in China, Japan and the West. Topics include the monastic life, notable Zen masters, Zen\'s cultural impact, and enlightenment. This course is in the form of lectures and discussion with assigned midterm, paper, and final.
	
Students described this course as “excellent” and the readings, “interesting,” covering a wide range and depth of material.  Students enjoyed the open discussions during class and learned “something new every day.”
	
The course was taught by Professor LaFleur and visiting Professor Boehme along with a TA. Students enjoyed the different opinions that the professors brought during discussion and found all instructors to be accessible and eager to discuss course material outside of class.
	
In terms of the workload, one student commented that the class requires that students “not have an attachment but a profound connection to the material one learns or experiences.  That connection with Zen had to be constantly recalled throughout the semester, even during free time.”
